body:
This was reported in #2614 but we failed to reproduce it.

Let's give it another try. Please contract the open file limit for test sake, run your commands and send API requests repeatedly

```
ulimit -n 100
rclone rcd your_sftp:path -vvv --log-file bug.log
[open 2nd terminal]
pgrep -a -f rclone
curl http://localhost:5572 ???
[repeat API requests]
```

After it has run for a while and accumulated some open files, kill rclone with `kill -QUIT RclonePID`. 
This will produce a backtrace which is likely very long
Please attach your commands, log and trace after redacting secrets here (or on gist.hithub.com or pastebin).

Thank you.

I set the ulimit to 100 and tried but was finding it difficult to see the error show up in logs.
So I set the ulimit to **50**. Following which I ran:
`/usr/bin/rclone rcd --rc-user=service-user --rc-pass=password --rc-web-gui --rc-addr=0.0.0.0:5572 -vvv --log-file /home/ubuntu/logs/bug.log`

You can find the log trace [here](https://gist.github.com/mchrisson/d2e595705119f1b8b8d098ddf1b74fe2)

Also max count I got from running `lsof | grep "rclone" | wc -l` was `240`.

I did see this `socket: too many open files` in many places in the log immediately. But then it went away.

Also note, the multiple SFTP storages I created all point to the same remote machine. But different directories. _(this is how it fits my use-case)_
also, I had a scheduler triggering multiple request to my nodeJS API which in turn talks to rclone API to 'operation/list' or move files.

Thanks for the log - very useful.

From the traceback I see groups of 26 goroutines which are likely the problem. Ultimately these are all causeed by `sftp.(*Fs).sftpConnection` which is the sftp backends routine to create a new connection.

I think each connection must be using 2 sockets to get to your ulimit of 50.

The SFTP backend takes care to re-use connections in its connection pool but it doesn't ever purge connections.

```
26: IO wait [0~13 minutes] [Created by ssh.newClientTransport @ handshake.go:134]
    poll    netpoll.go:220        runtime_pollWait(*, 0x72, #6)
    poll    fd_poll_runtime.go:87 (*pollDesc).wait(*, 0x72, *, 0x1000, 0x1000)
    poll    fd_poll_runtime.go:92 (*pollDesc).waitRead(...)
    poll    fd_unix.go:159        (*FD).Read(*, *, 0x1000, 0x1000, 0, 0, 0)
    net     fd_posix.go:55        (*netFD).Read(*, *, 0x1000, 0x1000, 0x5d243e, *, 0x10)
    net     net.go:182            (*conn).Read(*, *, 0x1000, 0x1000, 0, 0, 0)
    bufio   bufio.go:227          (*Reader).Read(*, *, 0x4, 0x4, *, *, *)
    io      io.go:314             ReadAtLeast(#4, *, *, 0x4, 0x4, 0x4, 0x40d950, *, *)
    io      io.go:333             ReadFull(...)
    ssh     cipher.go:373         (*gcmCipher).readCipherPacket(*, *, #4, *, *, *, *, 0, 0)
    ssh     transport.go:130      (*connectionState).readPacket(*, *, *, 0x405d2e, *, *, *)
    ssh     transport.go:114      (*transport).readPacket(*, *, *, *, 0, 0)
    ssh     handshake.go:374      (*handshakeTransport).readOnePacket(*, *, *, *, *, 0, 0)
    ssh     handshake.go:197      (*handshakeTransport).readLoop(*)
26: sync.Cond.Wait [0~13 minutes] [Created by sftp.NewClientPipe @ client.go:173]
    runtime proc.go:312           goparkunlock(...)
    sync    sema.go:513           runtime_notifyListWait(*, *)
    sync    cond.go:56            (*Cond).Wait(*)
    ssh     buffer.go:94          (*buffer).Read(*, *, 0x4, 0x4, 0, 0, 0)
    ssh     channel.go:351        (*channel).ReadExtended(*, *, 0x4, 0x4, 0, *, 0, *)
    ssh     channel.go:528        (*channel).Read(*, *, 0x4, 0x4, *, 0x405edc, *)
    io      io.go:314             ReadAtLeast(#5, *, *, 0x4, 0x4, 0x4, 0x405835, *, *)
    io      io.go:333             ReadFull(...)
    sftp    packet.go:144         recvPacket(#5, *, *, *, 0x1, *, 0, 0)
    sftp    conn.go:22            (*conn).recvPacket(...)
    sftp    conn.go:75            (*clientConn).recv(*, 0, 0)
    sftp    conn.go:60            (*clientConn).loop(*)
26: sync.Cond.Wait [13~14 minutes] [Created by ssh.NewClient @ client.go:61]
    runtime proc.go:312           goparkunlock(...)
    sync    sema.go:513           runtime_notifyListWait(*, *)
    sync    cond.go:56            (*Cond).Wait(*)
    ssh     mux.go:110            (*mux).Wait(*, 0, 0)
    ssh     client.go:62          NewClient.func1(*)
26: sync.Cond.Wait [13 minutes] [Created by sftp.(*Fs).sftpConnection @ sftp.go:312]
    runtime proc.go:312           goparkunlock(...)
    sync    sema.go:513           runtime_notifyListWait(*, *)
    sync    cond.go:56            (*Cond).Wait(*)
    ssh     mux.go:110            (*mux).Wait(*, 0, 0)
    sftp    sftp.go:274           (*conn).wait(*)
26: chan receive [0~13 minutes] [Created by ssh.newMux @ mux.go:128]
    ssh     handshake.go:187      (*handshakeTransport).readPacket(*, *, *, *, 0, 0)
    ssh     mux.go:215            (*mux).onePacket(*, 0, 0)
    ssh     mux.go:190            (*mux).loop(*)
26: chan receive [13 minutes] [Created by ssh.newSession @ session.go:592]
    ssh     session.go:423        (*Session).wait(*, *, *, *)
    ssh     session.go:593        newSession.func1(*, *)
26: chan receive [13 minutes] [Created by ssh.NewClient @ client.go:59]
    ssh     client.go:138         (*Client).handleGlobalRequests(*, *)
26: select [13~14 minutes] [Created by ssh.newClientTransport @ handshake.go:135]
    ssh     handshake.go:268      (*handshakeTransport).kexLoop(*)
26: chan receive [13~14 minutes] [Created by ssh.NewClient @ client.go:60]
    ssh     client.go:147         (*Client).handleChannelOpens(*, *)
```

So there could be 3 causes of this I can think of

1. The SFTP backend was used concurrently by 26 routines at some point - this would have required 26 connections.
2. There is an SFTP connection leak somewhere, so connections are being made but not returned to the pool.
3. You are creating lots of different SFTP backends - currently the connection pool is never being cleared

I think looking at your log it is option 3 - you are continually creating SFTP backends. It look like from the log that the backends aren't being re-used though - each request is creating a new backend which is wrong.

It looks like you are creating lots of backends very quickly - I wonder if there is a race condition there...

Looking at the code, this looks like the cause of the problem.

Try this. It should make sure you only create one backend each time. However this still won't flush the connection pool when the backend is removed from the cache - that should be done too.

[v1.54.0-beta.4992.9b9bf0568.fix-4883-cache](https://beta.rclone.org/branch/fix-4883-cache/v1.54.0-beta.4992.9b9bf0568.fix-4883-cache/) on branch [fix-4883-cache](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/tree/fix-4883-cache) (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

issue.title: Too many open files

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--

Welcome :-) We understand you are having a problem with rclone; we want to help you with that!

If you've just got a question or aren't sure if you've found a bug then please use the rclone forum:

    https://forum.rclone.org/

instead of filing an issue for a quick response.

If you think you might have found a bug, please can you try to replicate it with the latest beta?

    https://beta.rclone.org/
    
If you can still replicate it with the latest beta, then please fill in the info below which makes our lives much easier.  A log with -vv will make our day :-)

Thank you

The Rclone Developers

-->

#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
Syncing a directory with SFTP will fail after some time, yielding errors 'too many open files'. Running the command `lsof -c rclone | wc -l` yields 1029 (this is the max. I guess). In the list printed by `lsof -c rclone`, most protocols are of type 'can't identify protocol'

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
rclone v1.43.1
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.11


#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)
Windows 10 64 bit using Linux subsystem


####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)
SFTP


#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
rclone sync (local directory) (sftp connection) -P


#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (eg output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

body:
@ncw  You wrote: Try this. It should make sure you only create one backend each time. However this still won't flush the connection pool when the backend is removed from the cache - that should be done too. 
v1.54.0-beta.4992.9b9bf0568.fix-4883-cache on branch fix-4883-cache (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

I've uploaded that file and run it (Windows Server 2012 using sync to Asustor NAS via sftp)  I am still getting the issue
My max limit is over 7600 and i am hitting that many threads / processes in under three minutes. this then crashes the Asustor - requiring reboot. 

C:\Utils\rclone>rclone --version
 > rclone v1.54.0-beta.4992.9b9bf0568.fix-4883-cache
 > - os/arch: windows/386
 > - go version: go1.15.6
- 
Unfortuntely that files doesnt fix the issue
. Stopping the rclone process short of the asustor crqashing does not release the threads / processes    10 minutes in and I've still got numerous processes.  Running pkill sorts them but then the rclone throws a wobbly and cant restart. 

HTH
Shane
@OIITCONZ thanks for testing. Can you run with `-vv` and attach the log please? I'll analyse and see where it is going wrong now! Thanks.

@ncw , just some more information.

I kept a watch on the count from these two commands:
`netstat -anlp | grep rclone | wc -l`
and
`lsof | grep "rclone" | wc -l`

This just keeps growing.
When the count of netstat reaches 1017, that's when we start to see the "too many open files" error popping up. meanwhile the lsof count is around 7000-9000.

I believe that on each request like "operations/list" a new connection is established rather than re-using existing.

Also another interesting thing,
Even after I removed a remote-config (SFTP type)
Running netstat I could still see multiple SSH connections ESTABLISHED to that remote system and this connections never got released.
@mchrisson can you post a log with -vv from the test version I posted above?
@mchrisson just wondering if you saw the message above?

Hi @ncw, Took me time.

I have tried, v1.54.0-beta.4992.9b9bf0568.fix-4883-cache

But with no luck. The problem persists. The list of open files reached 1028. That's when it starts to give the errors.

```
root@server:/home/ubuntu# lsof -c rclone | wc -l
1028
root@server:/home/ubuntu# netstat -anlp | grep rclone | wc -l
1018
```

I ran rc operation/list :
```
root@server:/home/ubuntu/rclone# rclone rc operations/list --json '{"fs": "89664090-8552-478b-a4dd-28a189660c1a:", "remote":"PQ_Dropbox_mount"}' --rc-user=service-user --rc-pass=password -vvv --log-file /home/ubuntu/rclone/bug.log
root@server:/home/ubuntu/rclone# cat bug.log
2021/02/03 16:34:08 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.54.0-beta.4992.9b9bf0568.fix-4883-cache" starting with parameters ["rclone" "rc" "operations/list" "--json" "{\"fs\": \"89664090-8552-478b-a4dd-28a189660c1a:\", \"remote\":\"PQ_Dropbox_mount\"}" "--user=service-user" "--pass=password" "-vvv" "--log-file" "/home/ubuntu/rclone/bug.log"]
2021/02/03 16:34:19 DEBUG : 4 go routines active
2021/02/03 16:34:19 Failed to rc: Failed to read rc response: 500 Internal Server Error: {
        "error": "NewFs: couldn't connect SSH: dial tcp 15.97.199.24:22: socket: too many open files",
        "input": {
                "fs": "89664090-8552-478b-a4dd-28a189660c1a:",
                "remote": "PQ_Dropbox_mount"
        },
        "path": "operations/list",
        "status": 500
}
```

This took 2 days to start giving errors. But I sadly missed to include the -vvv and log while running the rcd.

Gathering the logs from rcd. Would post them soon.

Hi @ncw,

[here](https://gist.github.com/mchrisson/2dbb85027285a28b9953aa430405c538) is the log.

I am not able to get the backtrace after killing rclone. Re-trying again. Would post it here.
